comments:
This General Physics II course is taken in sequence with PHYS 101, General Physics I: Mechanics, Heat, and Sound. This course continues where PHYS 101 left off, emphasizing an introduction to classical electricity and magnetism, relativity theory, optics, and the quantum theory of matter, requiring a background in calculus.  This course is suggested for pre-health students and also fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement.

In Spring 2008, the course was taught 4 lectures a week by Professor Kikkawa and was taken with a co-requisite of the PHYS 120 lab.  Students raved about Professor Kikkawa’s teaching style, which they found to be straightforward and on-topic.  As one student wrote, Professor Kikkawa “is able to explain this difficult subject so that it is clear and understandable.”  Several students commented on the professor’s accessibility and willingness to talk to students outside of class.

Students were also pleased with the weekly quizzes, which they felt kept them on top of the material.  Several complained, however, about the amount of time in class spent going over homework problems, the answers to which were also posted online.  They felt that the time would have been better spent in normal lecture.

A continuation of General Physics I (recommended for pre-health students), this course surveys topics including electricity, magnetism, relativity theory, optics and the quantum theory of matter. This course fulfills the quantitative data analysis requirement and the physical world sector requirement for the College. Grades are based primarily on midterms, a final, quizzes and laboratory assignments. 

Students found the course challenging but said that Professor Arrison’s willingness to meet with them and explain difficult concepts helped a lot. Many students pointed out that Arrison was always willing to meet with them. One student summarized the general consensus, “Professor Arrison honestly wants everyone to succeed and goes beyond the call to provide extra problems, old exams, full solutions, etc.” 
 
Students also enjoyed his “laid-back and fun” lecturing style. Even though some found the material “extremely daunting,” Arrison helped the students get through difficult material. One student coming from a non-science major even commented, “I like Physics now!”
